She was buried in Raincy cemetery.<ref>"Au Raincy", ''[[Le Petit Parisien]]'', [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k518176f.pdf May 9, 1897].</ref> * Julia de Villiers de La Noue, Marquise de Bouthillier Chavigny (1844-1897) * Justine Waller, Comtesse Jules Couret de Villeneuve (1857-1897) * Mathilde de Weisweiller, Madame Théodore Porgès (1854-1897) * Elise Weyer (1836-1897), wife of Emile Hoskier, the Danish [[consul general]] in Paris, died together with her daughter Marie Hoskier (above), wife of the stockbroker Eugène Roland-Gosselin. * Germaine d'Yrenne de Lalanne, Comtesse d'Isoard Vauvenargues (1867-1897)
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List of victims of the Bazar de la Charite fire}} [[Category:Deaths from fire|+]] [[Category:Lists of victims|Bazar]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in France]] [[Category:1897 deaths|Bazar de le Charite]]

The concept of [[martyrdom]] is understood in the Western world as facing persecution and giving of one's life for a set of beliefs, most often religious beliefs. The definition of martyrdom is expanded in [[Iran]], where martyrs are greatly revered, including martyrs from the distant past as well as martyrs from the modern age. In Iran, [[Shia Islam]] is the majority religion, at 89% of the estimated 79 million inhabitants,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ir.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120203093100/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ir.html |archivedate=2012-02-03 |df= }}</ref> and is a very important part of public and political life. The Shia concept of Martyrdom has been shaped by the deaths of the early martyrs of the Shia faith, [[Ali]] and [[Husayn ibn Ali]], and Iranian society and government have further shaped the understanding of martyrdom in the modern age. The importance of Martyrdom in Shi'a Islam has brought about the existence of a type of "cult of martyrdom" in Iranian society.
==Shi'a roots== ===Martyrdom of Ali and Husayn=== {{Shia Islam}} After the death of the prophet Mohammad in the year 632, a disagreement arose between the followers of Mohammad as to who should be appointed as the prophets successor. The Muslims were split between two groups, those who supported [[Abu Bakr]], a companion of the prophet, and those who supported Ali, the prophet's cousin and son-in law. Ultimately, Abu Bakr became the first caliph, and his followers are today known as Sunni Muslims. The followers of Ali are known as Shia Muslims. Abu Bakr served for two years, and appointed [[Umar]] as his successor in 634. Umar served as caliph for ten years, during which he was responsible for the rapid spread of Islam through military and territorial gains. Upon his death in 644, a council of Islamic leaders elected a new Caliph, [[Uthman ibn Affan]], of the Umayyad family. However, in 656 supporters of Ali, who believed that a descendant of the prophet should lead the Muslim community, assassinated Uthman and installed [[Ali]] as the fourth caliph. Ali's reign was marred by numerous violent struggles between his supporters and the supporters of [[Muawiyah I]], a relative of Uthman and the governor of Syria. When Ali was murdered in the year 661 by a supporter of Muawiyah, he became the first martyr of the Shia faith. Ali had two sons, [[Hasan ibn Ali]] and Husayn, who the Shia believe continued their father's struggle in different ways. Hasan renounced his right to the caliphate in a compromise with Mu'awiya, which the Shi'a view as Hasan's rational recognition of his own constraints at the time, but Husayn sought to restore the caliphate to the family of Ali by military means. When Muawiyah died in the 680 and his son [[Yazid I]] assumed the caliphate, Husayn renewed his efforts to regain the caliphate. On the advice of supporters in [[Kufa]], a supposed stronghold of Shia support, Husayn and a small numbers of his family and supporters traveled to Kufa, camping out in nearby [[Karbala]]. However, the governor of Kufa was aware of Husayn's presence and sent close to 4000 troops to Karbala. After several days of failed negotiations, as Husayn refused to recognize Yazid as caliph, the governor's soldiers massacred Husayn and 72 of his men. This massacre, which occurred on the 10th day of the month of [[Muharram]], elevated the martyrdom of Husayn to almost mythical levels in Shia belief.<ref>Halm, Heinz 1997 Shi'a Islam; from Religion to Revolution. Princeton, New Jersey. Markus Weiner Publishers. pg. 4-16</ref>
==Cult of martyrdom in the public domain== ===Muharram and Ashura=== [[File:Mourning of Muharram in cities and villages of Iran-342 16 (47).jpg|thumb|Mourning of Muharram in Iran]] The Iranian concentration on the Martyrs of the past, especially the Imam Husayn, is evident during the Month of Muharram. The first ten days of this month are filled with public processions and demonstrations that recall the suffering of Husayn. These demonstrations have been occurring for hundreds of years. The explorer Thomas Herbert reported on his travels to the area now known as Iran in 1650, and gave this description of the events of Muharram: "I haue seene them nine seuer-all days in great multitudes, in the streets all together crying out Hussan Hussan."<ref>Halm, Heinz 1997 Shi'a Islam; from Religion to Revolution. Princeton, New Jersey. Markus Weiner Publishers. pg. 45</ref> During these ten days, mourners reenact the events at Karbala and pay respect to Husayn and several of his companions and family members who were also martyred.<ref>Halm, Heinz 1997 Shi'a Islam; from Religion to Revolution. Princeton, New Jersey. Markus Weiner Publishers. pg. 62</ref>
===Martyrs in the modern day=== In Iran today, those who died in the revolution and the soldiers who died in the Iran/Iraq War are also considered martyrs. These modern-day martyrs are also treated with great respect after their deaths. The special treatment of martyrs begins during the burial, as martyrs have special burial rites<ref>[[Zahra Kamalkhani|Kamalkhani, Zahra]] 1998 Women's Islam. New York, NY. Columbia University Press. pg. 70</ref> and the graves are well maintained, surrounded by Islamic flags, shady plants, framed pictures of the deceased, and beautiful carvings of Quranic verses.<ref>Kamalkhani, Zahra 1998 Women's Islam. New York, NY. Columbia University Press.</ref> Graveyards that hold the bodies of martyrs have taken on the characteristics of a public park, with families gathering to have picnics by the graves of their loved ones while listening to hired performers play music, recite poetry, or read verses from the Quran. The largest of these graveyards is the [[Behesht-e Zahra]], where there is even a theater that plays dramatic reenactments of battles from the war.<ref>https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/tehran/inside/martyrs.html</ref> The state does a lot to remind the public of the sacrifices of the dead even beyond the graveyard. After the Iran/Iraq war, many street names and school names were changed to the names of martyrs, and these names remain even today.<ref>Kamalkhani, Zahra 1998 Women's Islam. New York, NY. Columbia University Press. pg. 81</ref> Portraits of deceased soldiers are included in murals that line the streets, and pictures of martyrs hang from the walls in local mosques.<ref>Kamalkhani, Zahra 1998 Women's Islam. New York, NY. Columbia University Press. pg. 79</ref> Martyrs museums can be found in most major Iranian cities,<ref>http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1906049,00.html</ref> and there are even some camps where children of martyrs from the Iran/Iraq war can go to learn about the sacrifices of their fathers and sing songs from the revolution.<ref>https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/tehran/inside/martyrs.html</ref> Additionally, the themes of martyrdom are evident in children's textbooks from a very young age, with as much as 10 percent of the texts depicting themes of death and martyrdom.<ref>Farsoun, Samih and Mehrdad Mashayekhi 1991 Political Culture in the Islamic Republic. London, UK. Routledge.pg. 172</ref>
===Social mobility=== While the loss of a loved one is clearly a tragic and distressing event for a family, the families of martyrs in Iran were well taken care of. Having a martyr in the family meant immediate and permanent [[social mobility]] for many families. It was a mark of respect to have lost a son in the war, and the public displays honoring martyrs kept the memory of a family's loss alive in the community.<ref>Kamalkhani, Zahra 1998 Women's Islam. New York, NY. Columbia University Press. pg. 71</ref> Even beyond the social support of the community, the families of martyrs received certain tangible benefits. A large percentage of spots in many schools were reserved for the children of martyrs and having a martyr in the family gave a job applicant an edge against other applicants.<ref>Kamalkhani, Zahra 1998 Women's Islam. New York, NY. Columbia University Press. pg. 79</ref> Families of war martyrs were given certificates of martyrdom at the event of their child's death which gave them discounts for groceries and clothes.<ref>Reuter, Christoph 2004 My Life is a Weapon. Princeton, NJ. Princeton University Press. pg. 45</ref> Societies were set up for the sole purpose of helping the families martyrs or the "living martyrs" who were injured during the Iran/Iraq War. However, some families complained, especially later in the Iran/Iraq War, that their sacrifices were being increasingly ignored, and donations meant for martyrs' families were decreasing.<ref>Reuter, Christoph 2004 My Life is a Weapon. Princeton, NJ. Princeton University Press. pg. 50</ref>
==Politicization of martyrdom== ===Revolution=== [[File:Khordad222.jpg|300px|thumb|Protesters carrying the body of one of the victims]] The concept of martyrdom in Iranian society has played an important role in the major political conflicts of the past century. During the [[Iranian Revolution]] of 1979, revolutionary leaders such as Ayatollah [[Ruhollah Khomeini]] (link) reinterpreted the events of Karbala as a stand against oppression, using this narrative to strengthen the resolve of the people against Iran's leader at the time, Shah [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]]. Ayatollah Khomeini referred to Karbala and martyrdom many times in his speeches, most notably in the speech given on the eve of the Shah's departure from Iran "[Husayn] taught us that if a tyrant rules despotically over the Muslims in any age, we must rise up against him."<ref>Ram, Haggay 1994 ''Myth and Mobilization in Revolutionary Iran: The Use of the Friday Congregational Sermon''. Washington, D.C. The American University Press. pg. 68</ref> Khomeini labeled the Shah as "the Yazid of our time,"<ref>Reuter, Christoph 2004 ''My Life is a Weapon''. Princeton, NJ. Princeton University Press. pg. 43</ref> referring to the caliph of Husayn's time whose soldiers were responsible for the Karbala massacre. Popular slogans also reflected the importance of symbols of martyrdom, such as the slogan often seen on banners: "every land is Karbala, every month is Muharram, every day is Ashura."<ref>Reuter, pg. 42</ref> The revolutionaries therefore considered those who died at the hands of the Shah's secret police to be martyrs, especially those killed during the Black Friday Massacre (link), a clash between government troops and peaceful protestors that led to the deaths of around 100 people. The willingness of the revolutionaries to die for their cause in the name of martyrdom was a powerful tool in overthrowing the Shah. Major clashes with police would often occur in a 40-day cycle, as Iranian tradition demanded 40 days of mourning ending with public memorial processions for the deceased. The memorial processions of the martyrs of the revolution would thus turn into protest marches that led to more clashes with police and more deaths, starting the cycle over again and increasing the number of participants and therefore the strength of the revolution.<ref>Reuter, pg. 39</ref> Additionally, individuals participating in these protest marches would sometimes wear white burial cloths during the march to signify their willingness to die as martyrs for the cause. The symbolism of martyrdom provided a rallying point for the revolution and connected the events of the time with one of the most important historical narratives in Iranian culture, the massacre of Karbala and the martyrdom of Husayn.
===Iran–Iraq War=== [[File:Iranian killed soldier during Iran-Iraq war with Rouhollah Khomeini's photo on his uniform.jpg|upright=1.35|thumbnail|right|Iranian soldier killed during the Iran–Iraq War with [[Rouhollah Khomeini]]'s photo on his uniform]] The definition of a martyr broadened further during the [[Iran–Iraq War]] from 1980 to 1988. The extremely costly and destructive war between a Sunni-controlled country (Iraq) and a Shi'a-controlled country (Iran) had several parallels with the events at Karbala, which led to further exploitation of the Iranian reverence for martyrdom. [[Saddam Hussein]]'s Iraq was seen as the Sunni aggressor against the Shia people and therefore took on the role of the new Yazid in Iranian political discourse. Iranian leaders strongly emphasized the similarities between Karbala and the war with Iraq in order to retain public support for the war and keep the flow of volunteer soldiers steady. The death toll was extraordinarily high, with over a half a million dead on the Iranian side alone. To encourage volunteers, religious leaders broadened the definition of a martyr, announcing that all fatalities of the war were to be considered martyrs for the country, and therefore for Islam. Even Non-Muslim Iranian soldiers who sacrificed themselves in the line of duty were celebrated by the clerical regime. For example, Mehrdad Nahravand, a Zoroastrian Air Force pilot from the city of [[Gorgan]], who deliberately crashed his F-4 jet into a column of Iraqi Tanks after being shot down, was lauded as a 'martyr' despite his religion and statues of him were erected in his hometown. Similar was the case of Ardeshir Esfandpour, a Zoroastrian Helicopter pilot from the city of [[Mianeh, East Azerbaijan|Mianeh]] who after being shot down behind enemy lines in a battle near [[Ilam, Iran|Ilam]], deliberately called in an airstrike on his position on being captured by the Iraqis. Or Hoshang Nowshirwanian, a poor Zoroastrian carpenter from the city of [[Yazd]], who was conscripted into a [[Sapper]] battalion and single-handedly attacked an Iraqi Tank in order to save his commanding officer, for which the city council of Yazd commissioned a street name for him<ref>Ram, pg. 70</ref> Even those who did not die in battle but were wounded were called living martyrs- however this position did not bring as much social mobility as the families of those who died.<ref>Reuter, pg. 47</ref> Additionally, Iranian leaders would manufacture parallels between the war and the events at Karbala. In one memorable example, Iranian state television reported seventy-two deaths in a particularly bloody bombing in Iran. While in reality the death toll was higher, this fabricated number matched the number of Husayn's followers who were martyred in Karbala.<ref>Ram, pg. 72</ref> Battles were named Karbala Two, Three, and so on. Actors were hired to play the role of the [[Hidden Imam]] before dangerous battles, calling out to the soldiers to participate in suicide missions.<ref>Taheri, Amir 2009 ''The Persian Night: Iran under the Khomeinist Revolution''. New York, NY. Encounter Books. pg. 87</ref> The promise of immediate entrance to heaven for martyrs was a key point of emphasis for Iranian leaders. In speeches, religious officials often repeated the promise of seventy-two virgins, and young men were given keys to wear around their necks that supposedly granted them instant access to heaven upon death.<ref>Lankford, Adam 2009 ''Human Killing Machines''. Lanham, MD. Lexington Books. pg. 105</ref> Slogans on the soldiers' shirts read "Imam Khomeini has given me special permission to enter Heaven."<ref>Reuter, pg. 47</ref> 47 For those martyred in the war who were unmarried, wedding tables were set up above their graves, a tradition that came from the death of Qassim, a companion of Husayn at Karbala who was killed just before his wedding and whose body was placed in the tent where he was intended to be married.<ref>Reuter, pg. 48</ref> This emphasis on life after death and the comparisons to Hussein's martyrdom, one of the most important figures in Shi'a Islam, provided the Iranian state with volunteers for their human wave attacks, where young men would attack the fronts with little or no protection. Often martyrdom meant suicide missions on the battlefield, such as the famous example of the 13-year-old boy [[Mohammed Hossein Fahmideh]] who strapped explosives to his body and ran under an Iraqi tank. Such actions were widely publicized and praised as martyrdom.
===Iranian green movement=== [[File:Tehran protest (1).jpg|thumb|Protesters in Tehran carrying a long green textile as a sign of [[Iranian Green Movement]], 16 June]] Following the re-election of President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] in 2009, (It was a USA and Isreal Plot),protests concerning the validity of the vote and the possibility of voter-fraud broke out that led to thousands of arrests and close to a hundred deaths. During these protests, which became known as the [[Iranian Green Movement]], the theme of martyrdom was reclaimed by anti-government protestors as a form of "secular martyrdom." Activists in the 2009 green revolution began calling those killed during protests "martyrs." One important example is [[Neda Agha-Soltan]] a young student who was shot to death during a protest. A video of her death spread throughout the world, and her image became a symbol of resistance used to gain international political support. The fact that her name, Neda, means voice or calling in Persian, was also important, because it represented a call to martyrdom for the cause.<ref>http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1906049,00.html</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}

'''Neural top–down control of physiology''' concerns the direct regulation by the [[brain]] of [[Human homeostasis|physiological functions]] (in addition to [[smooth muscle]] and [[glandular]] ones). Cellular functions include the [[immune system|immune system’s]] production of [[T-lymphocytes]] and [[antibodies]], and nonimmune related [[homeostasis|homeostatic]] functions such as [[liver]] [[gluconeogenesis]], [[Renal sodium reabsorption|sodium reabsorption]], [[osmoregulation]], and [[brown adipose tissue]] [[thermogenesis#Non-shivering thermogenesis|nonshivering thermogenesis]]. This regulation occurs through the [[sympathetic nervous system|sympathetic]] and [[parasympathetic]] system (the [[autonomic nervous system]]), and their direct innervation of body organs and tissues that starts in the [[brainstem]]. There is also a noninnervation [[hormonal]] control through the [[hypothalamus]] and [[pituitary]] ([[Hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis|HPA]]). These lower brain areas are under control of [[cerebral cortex]] ones. Such cortical regulation differs between its [[Laterality|left and right sides]]. [[Pavlovian conditioning]] shows that brain control over basic cell level physiological function can be learnt.
==Higher brain==
===Cerebral cortex=== [[Sympathetic nervous system|Sympathetic]] and [[parasympathetic]] nervous systems and the [[hypothalamus]] are regulated by the higher brain.<ref name="Cerqueira">{{Cite journal | last1 = Cerqueira | first1 = J. O. J. | last2 = Almeida | first2 = O. F. X. | last3 = Sousa | first3 = N. | doi = 10.1016/j.bbi.2008.01.005 | title = The stressed prefrontal cortex. Left? Right! | journal = Brain, Behavior, and Immunity | volume = 22 | issue = 5 | pages = 630–638 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18281193 | pmc = }}</ref><ref name="Critchley">{{Cite journal | last1 = Critchley | first1 = H. D. | title = Neural mechanisms of autonomic, affective, and cognitive integration | doi = 10.1002/cne.20749 | journal = The Journal of Comparative Neurology | volume = 493 | issue = 1 | pages = 154–166 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16254997 | pmc = }}</ref><ref name="Van Eden">{{Cite book | last1 = Van Eden | first1 = C. G. | last2 = Buijs | first2 = R. M. | doi = 10.1016/S0079-6123(00)26006-8 | chapter = Functional neuroanatomy of the prefrontal cortex: autonomic interactions | title = Cognition, emotion and autonomic responses: The integrative role of the prefrontal cortex and limbic structures | series = Progress in Brain Research | volume = 126 | pages = 49–62 | year = 2000 | isbn = 9780444503329 | pmid = 11105639 | pmc = }}</ref><ref name="Craig">{{Cite journal | last1 = Craig | first1 = A. D. (B. | title = Forebrain emotional asymmetry: A neuroanatomical basis? | doi = 10.1016/j.tics.2005.10.005 | journal = Trends in Cognitive Sciences | volume = 9 | issue = 12 | pages = 566–571 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16275155 | pmc = }}</ref> Through them, the higher cerebral cortex areas can control the [[immune system]], and the body’s [[Homeostasis|homeostatic]] and [[Stress (biological)|stress]] physiology. Areas doing this include the [[insular cortex]],<ref name="Pacheco-Lopez, G. 2005">{{Cite journal | last1 = Pacheco-Lopez | first1 = G. | last2 = Niemi | first2 = M. B. | last3 = Kou | first3 = W. | last4 = Härting | first4 = M. | last5 = Fandrey | first5 = J. | last6 = Schedlowski | first6 = M. | title = Neural Substrates for Behaviorally Conditioned Immunosuppression in the Rat | doi = 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.4230-04.2005 | journal = Journal of Neuroscience | volume = 25 | issue = 9 | pages = 2330–2337 | year = 2005 | pmid = 15745959 | pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1006/brbi.1996.0011 | last1 = Ramírez-Amaya | first1 = V. | last2 = Alvarez-Borda | first2 = B. | last3 = Ormsby | first3 = C. E. | last4 = Martínez | first4 = R. D. | last5 = Pérez-Montfort | first5 = R. | last6 = Bermúdez-Rattoni | first6 = F. | title = Insular cortex lesions impair the acquisition of conditioned immunosuppression | journal = Brain, behavior, and immunity | volume = 10 | issue = 2 | pages = 103–114 | year = 1996 | pmid = 8811934 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Ramı́Rez-Amaya | first1 = V. | last2 = Bermudez-Rattoni | first2 = F. | doi = 10.1006/brbi.1998.0547 | title = Conditioned Enhancement of Antibody Production is Disrupted by Insular Cortex and Amygdala but Not Hippocampal Lesions | journal = Brain, Behavior, and Immunity | volume = 13 | issue = 1 | pages = 46–60 | year = 1999 | pmid = 10371677 | pmc = }}</ref> the [[Orbitofrontal cortex|orbital]], and the [[Middle frontal gyrus|medial prefrontal cortices]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Ohira | first1 = H. | last2 = Isowa | first2 = T. | last3 = Nomura | first3 = M. | last4 = Ichikawa | first4 = N. | last5 = Kimura | first5 = K. | last6 = Miyakoshi | first6 = M. | last7 = Iidaka | first7 = T. | last8 = Fukuyama | first8 = S. | last9 = Nakajima | first9 = T. | doi = 10.1016/j.neuroimage.2007.08.017 | last10 = Yamada | first10 = J. | title = Imaging brain and immune association accompanying cognitive appraisal of an acute stressor | journal = NeuroImage | volume = 39 | issue = 1 | pages = 500–514 | year = 2008 | pmid = 17913515 | pmc = }}</ref><ref name="Vlajkovic, S. 1994">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.3109/00207459408986051 | last1 = Vlajković | first1 = S. | last2 = Nikolić | first2 = V. | last3 = Nikolić | first3 = A. | last4 = Milanović | first4 = S. | last5 = Janković | first5 = B. D. | title = Asymmetrical modulation of immune reactivity in left- and right-biased rats after ipsilateral ablation of the prefrontal, parietal and occipital brain neocortex | journal = The International Journal of Neuroscience | volume = 78 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 123–134 | year = 1994 | pmid = 7829286 }}</ref> These cerebral areas also control smooth muscle and glandular physiological processes through the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous system including [[Cardiovascular physiology|blood circulation]], [[urogenital system|urogenital]], [[gastrointestinal]]<ref name="Pocai, A. 2005">{{Cite journal | last1 = Pocai | first1 = A. | last2 = Obici | first2 = S. | last3 = Schwartz | first3 = G. J. | last4 = Rossetti | first4 = L. | title = A brain-liver circuit regulates glucose homeostasis | doi = 10.1016/j.cmet.2004.11.001 | journal = Cell Metabolism | volume = 1 | issue = 1 | pages = 53–61 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16054044 | pmc = }}</ref> functions, pancreatic gut secretions,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Love | first1 = J. A. | last2 = Yi | first2 = E. | last3 = Smith | first3 = T. G. | doi = 10.1016/j.autneu.2006.10.001 | title = Autonomic pathways regulating pancreatic exocrine secretion | journal = Autonomic Neuroscience | volume = 133 | issue = 1 | pages = 19–34 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17113358 | pmc = }}</ref> [[respiration (physiology)|respiration]], [[coughing]], [[vomiting]], [[piloerection]], [[pupil]] dilation, [[crying|lacrimation]] and [[salivation]].<ref name="Brading">{{Cite book|last=Brading|first= A.|year=1999|title= The autonomic nervous system and its effectors|location= Oxford|publisher= Blackwell Science|isbn= 978-0-632-02624-1}}</ref>
===Lateralization === The sympathetic nervous system is predominantly controlled by the right side of the brain (focused upon the insular cortex), while the left side predominantly controls the parasympathetic nervous system.<ref name="Craig"/> The cerebral cortex in rodents shows [[lateralization|lateral specialization]] in its regulation of immunity with immunosuppression being controlled by the right hemisphere, and immunopotention by the left one.<ref name="Vlajkovic, S. 1994"/><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0006-8993(88)90458-1 | last1 = Barnéoud | first1 = P. | last2 = Neveu | first2 = P. J. | last3 = Vitiello | first3 = S. | last4 = Mormède | first4 = P. | last5 = Le Moal | first5 = M. | title = Brain neocortex immunomodulation in rats | journal = Brain Research | volume = 474 | issue = 2 | pages = 394–398 | year = 1988 | pmid = 3145098 }}</ref> Humans show similar lateral specialized control of the immune system from the evidence of [[stroke]]s,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Koch | first1 = H. J. | last2 = Uyanik | first2 = G. | last3 = Bogdahn | first3 = U. | last4 = Ickenstein | first4 = G. W. | title = Relation between Laterality and Immune Response after Acute Cerebral Ischemia | doi = 10.1159/000092108 | journal = Neuroimmunomodulation | volume = 13 | issue = 1 | pages = 8–12 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16612132 | pmc = }}</ref> surgery to control [[epilepsy#Surgical treatment|epilepsy]],<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Meador | first1 = K. J. | last2 = Loring | first2 = D. W. | last3 = Ray | first3 = P. G. | last4 = Helman | first4 = S. W. | last5 = Vazquez | first5 = B. R. | last6 = Neveu | first6 = P. J. | doi = 10.1002/ana.20105 | title = Role of cerebral lateralization in control of immune processes in humans | journal = Annals of Neurology | volume = 55 | issue = 6 | pages = 840–844 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15174018 | pmc = }}</ref> and the application of [[Transcranial magnetic stimulation|TMS]].<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0167-8760(02)00093-4 | last1 = Clow | first1 = A. | last2 = Lambert | first2 = S. | last3 = Evans | first3 = P. | last4 = Hucklebridge | first4 = F. | last5 = Higuchi | first5 = K. | title = An investigation into asymmetrical cortical regulation of salivary S-IgA in conscious man using transcranial magnetic stimulation | journal = International Journal of Psychophysiology | volume = 47 | issue = 1 | pages = 57–64 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12543446 }}</ref>
==Brainstem== The higher brain top down control of physiology is mediated by the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems in the brainstem,<ref name="Cerqueira"/><ref name="Critchley"/><ref name="Van Eden" /><ref name="Craig"/> and the hypothalamus.<ref name="Cerqueira"/><ref name="Radley" >{{Cite journal | last1 = Radley | first1 = J. J. | last2 = Arias | first2 = C. M. | last3 = Sawchenko | first3 = P. E. | doi = 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.4297-06.2006 | title = Regional Differentiation of the Medial Prefrontal Cortex in Regulating Adaptive Responses to Acute Emotional Stress | journal = Journal of Neuroscience | volume = 26 | issue = 50 | pages = 12967–12976 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17167086 | pmc = }}</ref><ref name="Kern">{{Cite journal | last1 = Kern | first1 = S. | last2 = Oakes | first2 = T. R. | last3 = Stone | first3 = C. K. | last4 = McAuliff | first4 = E. M. | last5 = Kirschbaum | first5 = C. | last6 = Davidson | first6 = R. J. | author6-link = Richard Davidson | doi = 10.1016/j.psyneuen.2008.01.010 | title = Glucose metabolic changes in the prefrontal cortex are associated with HPA axis response to a psychosocial stressor | journal = Psychoneuroendocrinology | volume = 33 | issue = 4 | pages = 517–529 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18337016 | pmc =2601562 }}</ref> The sympathetic nervous system arises in brainstem nuclei that project down into intermediolateral columns of [[Lateral horn of spinal cord|thoracolumbar]] spinal cord neurons in [[spinal cord|spinal segments]] T1–L2. The parasympathetic nervous system in the motor nuclei of [[cranial nerves]] III, VII, IX, (control over the pupil and salivary glands) and X (vagus –many functions including immunity) and sacral spinal segments (gastrointestinal and urogenital systems).<ref name="Brading"/> Another control occurs through top down control by the medial areas of the [[prefrontal cortex]].<ref name="Cerqueira"/><ref name="Radley" /><ref name="Kern"/> upon the [[hypothalamus]] which has a nonnerve control of the body through [[hormonal]] secretions of the [[pituitary]].
===Immunity=== The brain controls immunity both indirectly through HPA [[glucocorticoid]] secretions from the pituitary, and by various direct innervations.<ref name="Sternberg">{{Cite journal | last1 = Sternberg | first1 = E. M. | title = Neural regulation of innate immunity: A coordinated nonspecific host response to pathogens | doi = 10.1038/nri1810 | journal = Nature Reviews Immunology | volume = 6 | issue = 4 | pages = 318–328 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16557263 | pmc =1783839 }}</ref>
* Antibodies. There is sympathetic innervation of the [[thymus gland]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Trotter | first1 = R. N. | last2 = Stornetta | first2 = R. L. | last3 = Guyenet | first3 = P. G. | last4 = Roberts | first4 = M. R. | title = Transneuronal mapping of the CNS network controlling sympathetic outflow to the rat thymus | doi = 10.1016/j.autneu.2006.06.001 | journal = Autonomic Neuroscience | volume = 131 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 9–20 | year = 2007 | pmid = 16843070 | pmc = }}</ref> Sympathetic control exists over [[antibody]] production,<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0008-8749(79)90129-1 | last1 = Besedovsky | first1 = H. O. | last2 = Del Rey | first2 = A. | last3 = Sorkin | first3 = E. | last4 = Da Prada | first4 = M. | last5 = Keller | first5 = H. H. | title = Immunoregulation mediated by the sympathetic nervous system | journal = Cellular immunology | volume = 48 | issue = 2 | pages = 346–355 | year = 1979 | pmid = 389444 }}</ref> and the modulation of [[cytokines|cytokine]] concentrations.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Kin | first1 = N. W. | last2 = Sanders | first2 = V. M. | title = It takes nerve to tell T and B cells what to do | doi = 10.1189/jlb.1105625 | journal = Journal of Leukocyte Biology | volume = 79 | issue = 6 | pages = 1093–1104 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16531560 | pmc = }}</ref> * Cellular immunity. An intact sympathetic nervous system is required to maintain full cellular immunoregulation as denervated mice do not produce and activate, for example, [[spleen|splenic]] suppressor T cells, or [[thymus|thymic]] [[Natural Killer T cell|NKT cells]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Li | first1 = X. | last2 = Taylor | first2 = S. | last3 = Zegarelli | first3 = B. | last4 = Shen | first4 = S. | last5 = O'Rourke | first5 = J. | last6 = Cone | first6 = R. E. | doi = 10.1016/j.jneuroim.2004.04.008 | title = The induction of splenic suppressor T cells through an immune-privileged site requires an intact sympathetic nervous system | journal = Journal of Neuroimmunology | volume = 153 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 40–49 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15265662 | pmc = }}</ref> * Organ inflammation. Sympathetic innervation of various organs<ref name="Sternberg"/> contacts macrophages and dendritic cells and can increase local inflammation including the kidney<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Veelken | first1 = R. | last2 = Vogel | first2 = E. -M. | last3 = Hilgers | first3 = K. | last4 = Amann | first4 = K. | last5 = Hartner | first5 = A. | last6 = Sass | first6 = G. | last7 = Neuhuber | first7 = W. | last8 = Tiegs | first8 = G. | doi = 10.1681/ASN.2007050552 | title = Autonomic Renal Denervation Ameliorates Experimental Glomerulonephritis | journal = Journal of the American Society of Nephrology | volume = 19 | issue = 7 | pages = 1371–1378 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18400940 | pmc =2440306 }}</ref> gut,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Straub | first1 = R. H. | last2 = Grum | first2 = F. | last3 = Strauch | first3 = U. | last4 = Capellino | first4 = S. | last5 = Bataille | first5 = F. | last6 = Bleich | first6 = A. | last7 = Falk | first7 = W. | last8 = Schölmerich | first8 = J. | last9 = Obermeier | first9 = F. | doi = 10.1136/gut.2007.125401 | title = Anti-inflammatory role of sympathetic nerves in chronic intestinal inflammation | journal = Gut | volume = 57 | issue = 7 | pages = 911–921 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18308830 | pmc = }}</ref> the skin,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Pavlovic | first1 = S. | last2 = Daniltchenko | first2 = M. | last3 = Tobin | first3 = D. J. | last4 = Hagen | first4 = E. | last5 = Hunt | first5 = S. P. | last6 = Klapp | first6 = B. F. | last7 = Arck | first7 = P. C. | last8 = Peters | first8 = E. M. J. | doi = 10.1038/sj.jid.5701079 | title = Further Exploring the Brain–Skin Connection: Stress Worsens Dermatitis via Substance P-dependent Neurogenic Inflammation in Mice | journal = Journal of Investigative Dermatology | volume = 128 | issue = 2 | pages = 434–446 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17914449 | pmc = }}</ref> and the [[synovial joints]]<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Miller | first1 = L. E. | last2 = Jüsten | first2 = H. P. | last3 = Schölmerich | first3 = J. | last4 = Straub | first4 = R. H. | title = The loss of sympathetic nerve fibers in the synovial tissue of patients with rheumatoid arthritis is accompanied by increased norepinephrine release from synovial macrophages | doi = 10.1096/fj.99-1082com | journal = The FASEB Journal | volume = 14 | issue = 13 | pages = 2097–2107 | year = 2000 | pmid = 11023994 | pmc = }}</ref> * Antiinflammation. The vagus nerve carries a parasympathetic [[cholinergic]] antiinflammatory pathway that reduces [[proinflammatory cytokine]]s such as [[Tumor necrosis factors|TNF]] by spleen [[macrophages]] in the [[red pulp]] and the [[marginal zone]] and so the activation of [[inflammation]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Huston | first1 = J. M. | last2 = Ochani | first2 = M. | last3 = Rosas-Ballina | first3 = M. | last4 = Liao | first4 = H. | last5 = Ochani | first5 = K. | last6 = Pavlov | first6 = V. A. | last7 = Gallowitsch-Puerta | first7 = M. | last8 = Ashok | first8 = M. | last9 = Czura | first9 = C. J. | last10 = Foxwell | first10 = B. | last11 = Tracey | first11 = K. J. | last12 = Ulloa | first12 = L. | title = Splenectomy inactivates the cholinergic antiinflammatory pathway during lethal endotoxemia and polymicrobial sepsis | doi = 10.1084/jem.20052362 | journal = Journal of Experimental Medicine | volume = 203 | issue = 7 | pages = 1623–1628 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16785311 | pmc =2118357 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Rosas-Ballina | first1 = M. | last2 = Ochani | first2 = M. | last3 = Parrish | first3 = W. R. | last4 = Ochani | first4 = K. | last5 = Harris | first5 = Y. T. | last6 = Huston | first6 = J. M. | last7 = Chavan | first7 = S. | last8 = Tracey | first8 = K. J. | title = Splenic nerve is required for cholinergic antiinflammatory pathway control of TNF in endotoxemia | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 105 | issue = 31 | pages = 11008–11013 | year = 2008 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0803237105 | pmid=18669662 | pmc=2504833}}</ref> This control is in part controlled by direct innervation of body organs such as the spleen.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Exton | first1 = M. S. | last2 = Schult | first2 = M. | last3 = Donath | first3 = S. | last4 = Strubel | first4 = T. | last5 = Bode | first5 = U. | last6 = Del Rey | first6 = A. | last7 = Westermann | first7 = J. | last8 = Schedlowski | first8 = M. | title = Conditioned immunosuppression makes subtherapeutic cyclosporin effective via splenic innervation | journal = The American Journal of Physiology | volume = 276 | issue = 6 Pt 2 | pages = R1710–R1717 | year = 1999 | pmid = 10362751 }}</ref> However, the existence of the parasympathetic antiinflammatory nerve pathway is controversial with one reviewer stating: “there is no evidence for an anti-inflammatory role of the efferent vagus nerve that is independent of the sympathetic nervous system.”<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Nance | first1 = D. M. | last2 = Sanders | first2 = V. M. | doi = 10.1016/j.bbi.2007.03.008 | title = Autonomic innervation and regulation of the immune system (1987–2007) | journal = [[Brain, Behavior, and Immunity]] | volume = 21 | issue = 6 | pages = 736–745 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17467231 | pmc =1986730 }} p. 741</ref>
===Metabolism=== The [[liver]] receives both sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous system innervation.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Uyama | first1 = N. | last2 = Geerts | first2 = A. | last3 = Reynaert | first3 = H. | doi = 10.1002/ar.a.20086 | title = Neural connections between the hypothalamus and the liver | journal = The Anatomical Record | volume = 280A | issue = 1 | pages = 808–820 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15382020 | pmc = }}</ref> * [[Blood sugar|Plasma glucose levels]]. A vagus brain-liver axis exists that detects [[lipids]] produced by the [[intestine|gut]] and acts to regulate [[Blood sugar#Regulation|glucose homeostasis]].<ref name="Pocai, A. 2005"/><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Wang | first1 = P. Y. T. | last2 = Caspi | first2 = L. | last3 = Lam | first3 = C. K. L. | last4 = Chari | first4 = M. | last5 = Li | first5 = X. | last6 = Light | first6 = P. E. | last7 = Gutierrez-Juarez | first7 = R. | last8 = Ang | first8 = M. | last9 = Schwartz | first9 = G. J. | doi = 10.1038/nature06852 | last10 = Lam | first10 = T. K. T. | title = Upper intestinal lipids trigger a gut–brain–liver axis to regulate glucose production | journal = Nature | volume = 452 | issue = 7190 | pages = 1012–1016 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18401341 | pmc = }}</ref> * [[Glycogenesis]]. Vagal activation also controls [[glycogen]] synthesis in the liver.<ref name="Shimazu">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1007/BF00254502 | last1 = Shimazu | first1 = T. | title = Central nervous system regulation of liver and adipose tissue metabolism | journal = Diabetologia | volume = 20 Suppl | issue = 3 | pages = 343–356 | year = 1981 | pmid = 7014330 }}</ref> * [[lipogenesis]]. Vagal activation also controls the generation of [[lipids]] in [[brown adipose tissue]].<ref name="Shimazu"/> * [[Insulin]]. Vagal innervation of the [[pancreas]] controls the release of insulin release from its [[beta cells]] (and this is inhibited by norepinephrine released under sympathetic control from the [[splanchnic nerve]]).<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Brunicardi | first1 = F. C. | last2 = Shavelle | first2 = D. M. | last3 = Andersen | first3 = D. K. | title = Neural regulation of the endocrine pancreas | journal = International Journal of Pancreatology | volume = 18 | issue = 3 | pages = 177–195 | year = 1995 | doi = 10.1007/BF02784941 | pmid = 8708389 | pmc = }}</ref> * [[Triiodothyronine|Thyroid hormones]] can control glucose production via the hypothalamus and its sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation of the liver.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Klieverik | first1 = L. P. | last2 = Janssen | first2 = S. F. | last3 = Riel | first3 = A. V. | last4 = Foppen | first4 = E. | last5 = Bisschop | first5 = P. H. | last6 = Serlie | first6 = M. J. | last7 = Boelen | first7 = A. | last8 = Ackermans | first8 = M. T. | last9 = Sauerwein | first9 = H. P. | last10 = Fliers | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0805355106 | first10 = E. | last11 = Kalsbeek | first11 = A. | title = Thyroid hormone modulates glucose production via a sympathetic pathway from the hypothalamic paraventricular nucleus to the liver | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 106 | issue = 14 | pages = 5966–5971 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19321430 | pmc =2660059 }}</ref>
===Other === * [[Thermogenesis]] – this is controlled by the sympathetic nervous system starting in the dorsolateral [[preoptic area]] of the [[Anterior hypothalamic nucleus|anterior hypothalamus]] via projections from the [[nucleus raphe pallidus|rostral raphe pallidus]] to the spinal [[intermediolateral nucleus]] [[Thermogenesis#Non-shivering thermogenesis|nonshivering thermogenesis]] by brown adipose tissue.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Nakamura | first1 = K. | last2 = Morrison | first2 = S. F. | doi = 10.1152/ajpregu.00427.2006 | title = Central efferent pathways mediating skin cooling-evoked sympathetic thermogenesis in brown adipose tissue | journal = AJP: Regulatory, Integrative and Comparative Physiology | volume = 292 | issue = 1 | pages = R127–R136 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16931649 | pmc =2441894 }}</ref> * [[Stress (biological)|Stress]] – [[norepinephrine]] and [[epinephrine]], the [[stress hormone]]s, are released from nerve terminals in the [[adrenal medulla]] in the kidney innervated from the sympathetic nervous system’s [[splanchnic nerve]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Edwards | first1 = A. V. | last2 = Jones | first2 = C. T. | title = Autonomic control of adrenal function | journal = Journal of Anatomy | volume = 183 | issue = Pt 2 | pages = 291–307 | year = 1993 | pmid = 8300417 | pmc = 1259909 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Engeland | first1 = W. | title = Functional Innervation of the Adrenal Cortex by the Splanchnic Nerve | doi = 10.1055/s-2007-978890 | journal = Hormone and Metabolic Research | volume = 30 | issue = 6/07 | pages = 311–314 | year = 2007 | pmid = 9694555 | pmc = }}</ref> * Kidney function – the sympathetic nervous system projects to the [[kidney]] and controls [[Renal function#Glomerular filtration rate|glomerular filtration rate]] and so [[fluid balance]], [[Renal sodium reabsorption|sodium reabsorption]], and [[osmoregulation]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Dibona | first1 = G. F. | title = Neural control of the kidney: Functionally specific renal sympathetic nerve fibers | journal = American Journal of Physiology. Regulatory, Integrative and Comparative Physiology | volume = 279 | issue = 5 | pages = R1517–R1524 | year = 2000 | pmid = 11049831 | doi=10.1152/ajpregu.2000.279.5.r1517 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Denton | first1 = K. M. | last2 = Luff | first2 = S. E. | last3 = Shweta | first3 = A. | last4 = Anderson | first4 = W. P. | title = Differential Neural Control of Glomerular Ultrafiltration | doi = 10.1111/j.1440-1681.2004.04002.x | journal = Clinical and Experimental Pharmacology and Physiology | volume = 31 | issue = 5–6 | pages = 380–386 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15191417 | pmc = }}</ref>
==Conditioning== The brains of animals can anticipatorily learn to control cell level physiology such as immunity through [[Pavlovian conditioning]]. In this conditioning, a neutral [[Stimulus (physiology)|stimulus]] [[saccharin]] is paired in a drink with an agent, [[cyclophosphamide]], that produces an unconditioned response ([[immunosuppressive|immunosuppression]]). After learning this pairing, the taste of saccharin by itself through neural top down control created immunosuppression, as a new conditioned response.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Ader | first1 = R. | last2 = Cohen | first2 = N. | title = Behaviorally conditioned immunosuppression | journal = Psychosomatic Medicine | volume = 37 | issue = 4 | pages = 333–340 | year = 1975 | pmid = 1162023 | doi=10.1097/00006842-197507000-00007 }}</ref> This work was originally done on rats, however, the same conditioning can also occur in humans.<ref name="Goebel, M. U. 2002">{{Cite journal | last1 = Goebel | first1 = M. U. | last2 = Trebst | first2 = A. E. | last3 = Steiner | first3 = J. | last4 = Xie | first4 = Y. F. | last5 = Exton | first5 = M. S. | last6 = Frede | first6 = S. | last7 = Canbay | first7 = A. E. | last8 = Michel | first8 = M. C. | last9 = Heemann | first9 = U. | last10 = Schedlowski | first10 = M. | title = Behavioral conditioning of immunosuppression is possible in humans | doi = 10.1096/fj.02-0389com | journal = The FASEB Journal | volume = 16 | issue = 14 | pages = 1869–1873 | year = 2002 | pmid = 12468450 | pmc = }}</ref> The conditioned response happens in the brain with the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus providing the output pathway to the immune system, the amygdala, the input of visceral information, and the insular cortex acquires and creates the conditioned response.<ref name="Pacheco-Lopez, G. 2005"/> The production of different components of the immune system can be controlled as conditioned responses: * Antibodies<ref name="Goebel, M. U. 2002"/><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1006/nlme.1995.1048 | last1 = Alvarez-Borda | first1 = B. | last2 = Ramírez-Amaya | first2 = V. | last3 = Pérez-Montfort | first3 = R. | last4 = Bermúdez-Rattoni | first4 = F. | title = Enhancement of antibody production by a learning paradigm | journal = Neurobiology of learning and memory | volume = 64 | issue = 2 | pages = 103–105 | year = 1995 | pmid = 7582817 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0889-1591(02)00031-4 | last1 = Oberbeck | first1 = R. | last2 = Kromm | first2 = A. | last3 = Exton | first3 = M. S. | last4 = Schade | first4 = U. | last5 = Schedlowski | first5 = M. | title = Pavlovian conditioning of endotoxin-tolerance in rats | journal = Brain, behavior, and immunity | volume = 17 | issue = 1 | pages = 20–27 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12615046 }}</ref> *IL-2<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Pacheco-López | first1 = G. | last2 = Niemi | first2 = M. -B. | last3 = Kou | first3 = W. | last4 = Härting | first4 = M. | last5 = Del Rey | first5 = A. | last6 = Besedovsky | first6 = H. O. | last7 = Schedlowski | first7 = M. | doi = 10.1016/j.neuroscience.2004.08.033 | title = Behavioural endocrine immune-conditioned response is induced by taste and superantigen pairing | journal = Neuroscience | volume = 129 | issue = 3 | pages = 555–562 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15541877 | pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0165-5728(98)00122-2 | last1 = Exton | first1 = M. S. | last2 = Von Hörsten | first2 = S. | last3 = Schult | first3 = M. | last4 = Vöge | first4 = J. | last5 = Strubel | first5 = T. | last6 = Donath | first6 = S. | last7 = Steinmüller | first7 = C. | last8 = Seeliger | first8 = H. | last9 = Nagel | first9 = E. | last10 = Westermann | first10 = J. R. | last11 = Schedlowski | first11 = M. | title = Behaviorally conditioned immunosuppression using cyclosporine A: Central nervous system reduces IL-2 production via splenic innervation | journal = Journal of Neuroimmunology | volume = 88 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 182–191 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9688340 }}</ref> * B, CD8+ T cells and CD4+ naive and memory T cells, and granulocytes.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0165-5728(98)00011-3 | last1 = Von Hörsten | first1 = S. | last2 = Exton | first2 = M. S. | last3 = Schult | first3 = M. | last4 = Nagel | first4 = E. | last5 = Stalp | first5 = M. | last6 = Schweitzer | first6 = G. | last7 = Vöge | first7 = J. | last8 = Del Rey | first8 = A. | last9 = Schedlowski | first9 = M. | last10 = Westermann | first10 = J. R. | title = Behaviorally conditioned effects of Cyclosporine a on the immune system of rats: Specific alterations of blood leukocyte numbers and decrease of granulocyte function | journal = Journal of Neuroimmunology | volume = 85 | issue = 2 | pages = 193–201 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9630168 }}</ref> Such conditioning in rats can last a year.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1159/000026428 | last1 = Exton | first1 = M. S. | last2 = Von Hörsten | first2 = S. | last3 = Strubel | first3 = T. | last4 = Donath | first4 = S. | last5 = Schedlowski | first5 = M. | last6 = Westermann | first6 = J. | title = Conditioned alterations of specific blood leukocyte subsets are reconditionable | journal = Neuroimmunomodulation | volume = 7 | issue = 2 | pages = 106–114 | year = 2000 | pmid = 10686521 }}</ref> Nonimmune functions can also be conditioned: * [[Serum iron]] levels<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0091-3057(94)00353-X | last1 = Exton | first1 = M. S. | last2 = Bull | first2 = D. F. | last3 = King | first3 = M. G. | last4 = Husband | first4 = A. J. | title = Behavioral conditioning of endotoxin-induced plasma iron alterations | journal = Pharmacology Biochemistry and Behavior | volume = 50 | issue = 4 | pages = 675–679 | year = 1995 | pmid = 7617718 }}</ref> * The level of [[Oxidative stress|oxidative]] [[DNA oxidation|DNA damage]]<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0304-3940(00)01194-0 | last1 = Irie | first1 = M. | last2 = Asami | first2 = S. | last3 = Nagata | first3 = S. | last4 = Miyata | first4 = M. | last5 = Kasai | first5 = H. | title = Classical conditioning of oxidative DNA damage in rats | journal = Neuroscience Letters | volume = 288 | issue = 1 | pages = 13–16 | year = 2000 | pmid = 10869804 }}</ref> * [[Pulsatile insulin|Insulin secretion]]<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0166-4328(99)00192-8 | last1 = Stockhorst | first1 = U. | last2 = Steingrüber | first2 = H. J. | last3 = Scherbaum | first3 = W. A. | title = Classically conditioned responses following repeated insulin and glucose administration in humans | journal = Behavioural Brain Research | volume = 110 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 143–159 | year = 2000 | pmid = 10802311 }}</ref><ref name="Stockhorst">{{Cite journal | last1 = Stockhorst | first1 = U. | last2 = Mahl | first2 = N. | last3 = Krueger | first3 = M. | last4 = Huenig | first4 = A. | last5 = Schottenfeldnaor | first5 = Y. | last6 = Huebinger | first6 = A. | last7 = Berresheim | first7 = H. | last8 = Steingrueber | first8 = H. | last9 = Scherbaum | first9 = W. | doi = 10.1016/j.physbeh.2003.12.019 | title = Classical conditioning and conditionability of insulin and glucose effects in healthy humans | journal = Physiology & Behavior | volume = 81 | issue = 3 | pages = 375–388 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15135009 | pmc = }}</ref> * [[Plasma glucose|Blood glucose levels]]<ref name="Stockhorst"/><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0031-9384(93)90058-N | last1 = Fehm-Wolfsdorf | first1 = G. | last2 = Gnadler | first2 = M. | last3 = Kern | first3 = W. | last4 = Klosterhalfen | first4 = W. | last5 = Kerner | first5 = W. | title = Classically conditioned changes of blood glucose level in humans | journal = Physiology & Behavior | volume = 54 | issue = 1 | pages = 155–160 | year = 1993 | pmid = 8327595 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Autonomic nervous system]] * [[Homeostasis]] * [[Homeostatic emotion]] * [[Neurogastroenterology]] * [[Neuroendocrinology]] * [[Neuroimmunology]] * [[Parasympathetic nervous system]] * [[Peripheral nervous system]] * [[Psychoneuroimmunology]] * [[Sympathetic nervous system]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Use British English|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Peter Campbell | fullname = Peter Campbell | birth_date = 1850s | birth_place = [[Rhu, Argyll|Rhu]], [[Argyll]], Scotland | death_date = January 1883 | death_place = [[Bay of Biscay]] | position = [[Striker (association football)|Forward]] | years1 = 1872–1879 | years2 = 1879–1880 | clubs1 = [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] | clubs2 = [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] | caps1 = n/a | goals1 = | caps2 = n/a | goals2 = | nationalyears1 = 1878–1879 | nationalteam1 = [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] | nationalcaps1 = 2 | nationalgoals1 = 3 }} '''Peter Campbell''' (born late 1850s in [[Rhu, Argyll|Rhu]] in [[Argyll]]; died January 1883) was a Scottish [[football (soccer)|footballer]], who was one of the four founding members of [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers Football Club]]. He made 24 [[Scottish Cup]] appearances for Rangers and scored 15 goals.
==Club career== Along with fellow founding members [[Peter McNeil]], [[Moses McNeil]] and [[William McBeath]], Campbell played in Rangers' first ever match against [[Callander F.C.]] at ''Flesher's Haugh'', [[Glasgow Green]] in 1872. He continued to play for Rangers until 1879, helping the club to the [[Scottish Cup]] finals of 1877 and 1879. After his career at Ibrox, he played briefly for English club [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] for the [[1879-80 in English football|1879-80 season]] before retiring from football.<ref>[http://www.heraldscotland.com/rangers-the-forgotten-history-1.916995 "Rangers: The forgotten history"] Herald (20 August 2009)</ref>
On 22 February 2010 Peter Campbell was inducted into the Rangers Hall of Fame.
==International career== He also represented the [[Scotland national football team|Scotland national team]], playing twice against [[Wales national football team|Wales]] in 1878 and in 1879, scoring in both.
===International goals=== :''Scores and results list Scotland's goal tally first.'' {| class="wikitable" ! # !! Date !! Venue !! Opponent !! Score !! Result !! Competition |- |1 || 23 March 1878 || [[Hampden Park]], [[Glasgow]] ||{{fb|WAL}} || 1-0 || 9-0 || [[Friendly match|Friendly]] |- |2 || 23 March 1878 || [[Hampden Park]], [[Glasgow]] || {{fb|WAL}} || 3-0 || 9-0 || [[Friendly match|Friendly]] |- |3 || 7 April 1879 || [[Acton Park, Wales|Acton Park]], [[Wrexham]] || {{fb|WAL}} || 1-0 || 3-0 || [[Friendly match|Friendly]] |}
==Death== He died from [[drowning]] after his ship ''Saint Columba'' sank in the [[Bay of Biscay]] during a storm as it ferried coal from [[Wales|south Wales]] to [[Mumbai|Bombay]] in 1883.<ref>[http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/editors-choice/2009/07/14/revealed-the-curse-of-the-rangers-pioneers-86908-21518811/ "Revealed: The curse of the Rangers pioneers"] Daily Record (14 July 2009)</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{SFA profile}} *[http://www.londonhearts.com/scotland/players/peter1campbell.html International stats] at Londonhearts.com

Hall of Fame}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Campbell, Peter}} [[Category:1850s births]] [[Category:1883 deaths]] [[Category:Scottish footballers]] [[Category:Scotland international footballers]] [[Category:Rangers F.C. players]] [[Category:Blackburn Rovers F.C. players]] [[Category:Deaths by drowning]] [[Category:People from Rhu, Argyll and Bute]] [[Category:Deaths due to shipwreck]] [[Category:Association football forwards]]
